channel.title: What is UBUNTU?
channel.description: I realize now it's like some sort of downloadable plat form, I'm running a win 7 at the moment if I were to download it what would be the difference?

item.title: What is UBUNTU?
item.dc:creator: @Advocatus Advocatus
item.description:
@Advocatus wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:8, topic:420059”]kernel

Also .exe is just an extension - it’s just the libraries used to compile the application to machine-code that are system dependent. Linux distributes usually don’t use file extensions because file identifications are done via the file headers instead of just reading the filename extension.[/quote]
Thanks for that spelling catch.

Also, I guess that file identification via header is why I was perplexed when after writing some data to a binary file the file icon changed xD.

Read full topic

item.title: What is UBUNTU?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Advocatus, post:7, topic:420059”][quote author=t4 link=topic=522618.msg3801341#msg3801341 date=1320030183]
distribution
[/quote]

More specifically, its a linux distribution based on the debian codebase which is in turn based on the Linux kernal.

Basically, its a free operating system.
The benefits are that it is free, open source, and has customer support and a development team.
The downsides are that there is insignificant progress to porting the .NET framework to linux (yeah, we have mono, but running through it is much slower than running in windows). Also, .exe files are not naturally supported in linux. They have a better option for installing packages, either via terminal or through a package manager.[/quote]
kernel

Also .exe is just an extension - it’s just the libraries used to compile the application to machine-code that are system dependent. Linux distributes usually don’t use file extensions because file identifications are done via the file headers instead of just reading the filename extension.

Read full topic

item.title: What is UBUNTU?
item.dc:creator: @Advocatus Advocatus
item.description:
@Advocatus wrote:

t4:

distribution

More specifically, its a linux distribution based on the debian codebase which is in turn based on the Linux kernal.

Basically, its a free operating system.
The benefits are that it is free, open source, and has customer support and a development team.
The downsides are that there is insignificant progress to porting the .NET framework to linux (yeah, we have mono, but running through it is much slower than running in windows). Also, .exe files are not naturally supported in linux. They have a better option for installing packages, either via terminal or through a package manager.

Read full topic

item.title: What is UBUNTU?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

It’s an operating system (OS) that’s fast, secure and stylishly simple. The Ubuntu operating system is used by 20 million people worldwide every day. You can surf in safety with Ubuntu – confident that your files and data will stay protected. A built-in firewall and virus protection come as standard. And if a potential threat appears, we provide automatic updates which you can install in a single click. You get added security with AppArmor, which protects your important applications so attackers can’t access your system. And thanks to Firefox and gnome-keyring, Ubuntu helps you keep your private information private. So whether it’s accessing your bank account or sharing sensitive data with friends or colleagues, you’ll have peace of mind when you need it the most.

Ubuntu loads quickly on any computer, but it’s super-fast on newer machines. With no unnecessary programs and trial software slowing things down, booting up and opening a browser takes seconds. Unlike other operating systems that leave you staring at the screen, waiting to get online. And Ubuntu won’t grow sluggish over time. It’s fast. And it stays fast.

Accessibility is central to the Ubuntu philosophy. We believe that computing is for everyone regardless of nationality, race, gender or disability. Fully translated into 25 languages, Ubuntu also includes essential assistive technologies, which are, of course, completely free.

Try Ubuntu on a CD or USB stick here.
Run Ubuntu alongside Windows.
Download and install Ubuntu here.

Pictures: http://www.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/features/photos-and-videos
http://www.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/features

Read full topic
